conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area on the surface behind the object.
The size and position of the shadow depend on the angle and distance of the light source relative to the object.
There are four objects: a mushroom, a sculpture, a dress, and a book casting shadows A, B, C, and D respectively.
The light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows on the ground.
Moving the light source forward changes the angle at which light hits the objects, affecting shadow position and size.
As the light source moves forward, the angle of incidence on the objects becomes steeper.
Shadow A (Mushroom) will move backward as the light source moves forward.
Shadow B (Sculpture) will move backward as the light source moves forward.
Shadow C (Dress) will move backward as the light source moves forward.
Shadow D (Book) will move backward as the light source moves forward.
As the light source moves forward, shadows will generally become longer.
When the light source moves forward, shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward and become longer.
